Issues.Title: Mobile hero is either too small or too large (full height)
Issues.Body:
This is about Bulma.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **0.7.5**
My **browser** is: Google Chrome

### Description

The large hero on desktop shrinks to such a small size on mobile that the image is useless. A full height hero is too large. There's no in between.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Add large hero (is-large)
2. In mobile view, large hero shrinks drastically

### Expected behavior

To have a hero that covers half of the screen in mobile. What I'd imagine a large hero should look like.

### Actual behavior

is-large shrinks to a very small size.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Mobile hero is either too small or too large (full height)" (#2545)

Issues.Title: Container or Column not taking up the full available width of the screen
Issues.Body:
### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**

### Description

I have two columns: one for my vertical menu and another as my main content panel.
In my main content panel I have a container with a horizontal rule and a paragraph.

The container is not taking up all the available horizontal space on the screen unless I have a paragraph with a really long text.
Currently the container is only taking up the width of my longest element which is my paragraph.

### Steps to Reproduce

You can view the following example: https://codepen.io/howienoble/pen/qzRJvw
As you can see, the hr element is not taking up all the available horizontal space.

### Expected behavior

I would expect that either a column with the `is-full` attribute or a container with the `is-fullhd` attribute would use up all the available horizontal space available.

### Actual behavior

Neither my column nor my container are taking up all the available horizontal space.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Container or Column not taking up the full available width of the screen" (#2537)

Issues.Title: Min-width for tiling?
Issues.Body:
This is about Bulma, the CSS framework.

I think I have found a bug but I'm not sure if it's a bug or purposefully set that way.

I'm using Bulma 0.7.2

My browser is Firefox but it is identical in chrome.



### Overview of the problem

When setting the variable `$body-min-width`, this doesn't seem to prevent the tiles from changing as the website gets smaller.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a tiling layout (mine uses a 8-width and 4-width tile)
2. Set the min-width (I'm using 1024px)
3. Make the browser smaller than 1024px and note the tiling does not keep layout, it continues to change at certain breakpoints.


### Expected behavior

What I expected was that once smaller than 1024px the website would no longer change, but just get a scroll horizontal scroll bar.

Again, as I stated above, perhaps this is on purpose,but I just wanted to confirm. I'm not sure how else with Bulma one would create a min width that prevents the website from dynamically changing beyond a point.

NOTE that the website does get a horizontal scroll bar (if you set `$body-overflow-x: scroll;`) and that other things don't change but the tiling seems to be relative to the viewport width and therefore continues to change.

### Actual behavior

Refer to step 3 of "steps to reproduce"

### Sidenote

Huge fan of Bulma, thank you so much for making this awesome framework, let me know if there is anything else you need me to explain about the issue and I will happily.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Min-width for tiling?" (#2528)

Issues.Title: Responsive margin + paddings
Issues.Body:
### Responsive margins + paddings

I am sure that I am not the first one who needs a different margin and padding setting on tablet and on desktop devices etc.

So, it would be cool if you can do the following thing:

`<section class="section is-marginless-vertical-mobile has-margin-vertical-tablet"></section> `

By default, there are only these entries in the helper.sass:
```
.is-marginless
  margin: 0 !important

.is-paddingless
  padding: 0 !important
```

I've extended this having such things like:

```
is-marginless-tablet
is-paddingless-vertical
has-padding-horizontal
has-margin-vertical-desktop
```
If you don't need all variations (there are a lot...), you can control this by two arrays.

I attach the sass file and a sample output with all variations.

If this is also helpful for anybody else, I can do a pull request.

[margin_sample.css.txt](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/files/3276839/margin_sample.css.txt)

[margin_responsive.sass.txt](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/files/3276843/margin_responsive.sass.txt)


Best wishes,
Georg.

_PS: I luv Bulma!!!!_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Responsive margin + paddings" (#2527)

Issues.Title: Add .is-title-adjacent helper -- support for arbitrarily moving elements closer to titles (Fixes #2346)
Issues.Body: This is a **new feature**. Hi. This is my first time opening a pull request in Bulma! üëãüèª The .is-title-adjacent helper adds the ability to arbitrarily move any element which is below a title or a subtitle closer to that title or subtitle, in the same way that a subtitle automatically moves closer to a title. ### Proposed solution Some websites like to have things like bylines, post datetimes, or other things kept close to the post title area. This helper makes it easier to do this in Bulma without writing custom code. It fixes Issue #2346, which I filed in February. ### Tradeoffs The way this is written, it shouldn't impact those who have already written custom code to do this same thing, so that's thankfully *not* a tradeoff here. I don't see any reason why it adds any significant tradeoffs, though, of course, for more specific use cases, some users will continue to create their own custom classes. ### Testing Done The changes I've made are small, so they seem to work as intended. As I'm a first-time contributor, I wanted to submit this pull request with the intent of making sure that there isn't something I'm overlooking, but given the tests done both on my personal website and while updating the docs, things seem to look good. On my personal website, before the changes: My personal website, after the changes: Screenshot of my modifications to the documentation: ![Screenshot 2019-06-05 13 49 20](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/280610/58978062-0d09c180-8799-11e9-97c4-63ad6115d38c.png) ### Changelog updated? Yes. *edit: Updated screenshots with slightly smaller, better-looking (maybe) ones with the same content.*

Issues.Title: Fix inconsistent input[disabled] color in Safari. Fixes #2355
Issues.Body: This is a **bugfix**. ### Proposed solution Safari is rendering `disabled` input fields with faded text. Instead of the Bulma default `#7a7a7a` (48% luminosity), the input text renders at `#cecece` (81% luminosity). Multiple users reported confusion, thinking the ` value=` was instead `placeholder=` text, because it was so faded. Bulma is [already choosing to override the default `` text `color`](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/ff8c4c18accf2c0094aa77945b1d2180ac927159/sass/elements/form.sass#L67). That setting simply isn't taking effect in Safari & iOS Safari. Screenshots of the bug (top correct, bottom incorrect): This PR fixes it. ### Tradeoffs This adds a bit of browser-specific attributes to the codebase. A case could be made that's better handled by `normalize.css`. ### Testing Done Confirmed to work in production. ### Changelog updated? No.
